\ general call was here made for the Hon. John
Moore, who delivered a speech of great importance,
full of facts and figures, which will be found very-
interesting and is as follows :
"I respond to your call, fellow-citizens, cheerfully, and must
say that I am glad to see the citizens of New Orleans, and
the State generally, aroused on the subject of intercommunication by means of railroads. Whilst we have been
slumbering, our fellow-citizens of the Eastern States have
been constructing canals and railroads to every available
.oiiit in this great valley to draw off the trade from New
Orleans; even our Southern neighbors are taking the lead-
arid unless some active measures are taken to counteract the
tendency of these works, New Orleans must soon feel the
effects most wofully. I will detain you no longer with these
generalities, but will speak of the subject which brings us
logether. The project of a railroad from opposite this city
to Washington, six miles beyond Opelousas, passing through
Lafourche and Attakapas; giving the road such deviations
from a right line as will give the best route and insure the
greatest amount of business. It will make it, according to
my estimate, about 172 miles long; and I am of opinion that
it can be laid down within the estimate made by B. H. Payne,
Esq., S 1,(500,000.
That part of the route with which I am best acquainted,
trom Berwick's Bay to Opelousas, presents fewer difficulties,
ami the railroad can be laid down as cheap, if not cheaper,
'rail any other railroad in Louisiana, or elsewhere—there
